These programs aim to reduce the number of firearms—especially high-risk weapons—in circulation by offering an incentive for individuals to turn in their guns. Importantly, these programs are voluntary, anonymous, and do not require individuals to disclose why they are surrendering their weapons.

Now, to your second question: **yes, gun buyback programs do help reduce gun violence in communities**, and there is a growing body of evidence to support this.

For example, in Australia, after a national gun buyback program was implemented following the 1996 Port Arthur massacre, there was a **54% reduction in firearm-related homicides and a 65% drop in firearm suicides** over the next decade. This is one of the most well-documented success stories and has been cited in numerous academic publications as a model for effective gun policy.

In the United States, while the data can be more complex due to the diversity of local conditions, cities like **Chicago and Boston** have seen meaningful reductions in gun violence after implementing targeted buyback programs.
